Renaissance -style liberal

Unfortunately, Hopkins' possible purchase of the
Baltimorean has aroused the ire of local residents. While we
can understand the community's natural response to having
housing units removed from the market, we feel they have
overreacted to what seems to us to be a reasonable
compromise between the University's need for more housing
and the Community's desire to preserve its neighborhoods
Of all the buildings in the area the Baltimorean seems to
deprive the community of the least housing, since many of
the residents are on short-term leases.
In addition, Hopkins, if anything, is likely to refurbish the
building. The very presence of the University on 29th Street
will probably increase the security provided in that
neighborhood, and consequently make it a safer place for all
residents to live.
Moreover, we believe that the way the University has gone
about the proposed purchase of the Baltimorean has been in
the spirit of community cooperation. Hopkins has not yet
bought the building and has consulted the community
beforehand, as it said it would. Even the students are aware
of the need for increased communication and understanding
between the University and the Community, as evidenced by
the formation of the Student Council's Community Relations
Committee. We never expect area residents to be overjoyed
with a Hopkins purchase of a large bloc of housing, but they
should realize that the University—its students—have certain
needs which must be met in a reasonable manner. While we
realize that the Community may have been abused by
Hopkins in the past, we hope they will act in the spirit of
cooperation and consider the needs of others as we trust the
University will.

Recently, a serious problem
has come to my attention. Within

attention from students,

get what they came for

The time was right for an
honest to god spectacle at
Homewood. See, it had come to
the point where excitement
seekers were roaming around
campus with hands in pockets
and question mark faces, uttering
only an occasional "Hey man,
what's goin' on, any kicks to be
had around here?" It's true, the
novelty of the new school year
has evaporated, students are
starting to take classes and
studies seriously, gossip of
physics tests and organic labs are
filling the lunchroom. Yup, the
honeymoon is over.
When Carl Bernstein opened
the MSE Symposium last
Monday, some of us had hope
that the doldrums would be
dramatically interrupted. No
luck. Bernstein said nothing new,
all the funnies in his speech were
culled from his best seller, All the
President's Men. But wait, the
optimists cried out, Dr. Hunter S.
Thompson, the one and only
Raoul Duke, would be speaking

trip it would be. Bets were waged
as to whether he'd light up a
stick of dynamite Pago Pago
weed on stage, and if not that,
the podium would definitely be
flooded with Coors cans. "For
sure!" squealed the Thompson
freak.

was filled to capacity, housed
with the usual Symposium
attendees, but mostly with the
troops of Thompson's local
legions, all arriving with
pre-conceived notions of the
mass-appointed Gonzo Hero.
They were hardly disappointed
with the Symposium Wheels very
noticeably furnished the stage

glasses and a bottle of Wild
Turkey. Cheers thundered from
the crowd, and when he walked
on stage, well, you might have
thought Christ or even Charlie
Chaplin was making a rare guest
appearance. Scores of

conversations could be heard
from either side of the
auditorium, and you know what,
they were all the same! Listen to
this: "Man, I told you so. Look

fucked up all the time, he's so
cool, leave it to old Hunter S.

Vegas. Man, I bet he's stoned as
shit."

audience was wholly uninhibited,
shouting yay or nay to the
comments, openly hissing when
the Symposium Wheels asked
trite questions. No smoking signs
were blatantly ignored and fans
sat wherever they wanted, in the
seats, aisles, anywhere. A rowdier
crowd the Symposium had not
seen.
The canned format for the
performance was poorly planned.
The Wheels were intent on
keeping Thompson away from
drug or gonzo talk, the subjects
that everyone came to hear.
When Thompson began to
ramble, his manager,
conveniently seated in the center
first row, was quick to ask
political questions and put the
show back on target. But the
charade had to stop. After the

clear that things were not going
quite right. Finally, Thompson

journalism, Duke was able to

mumble something totally
predictable like,"Ah, Humphrey,
that no good swine," and zoom,
half the audience was yukking it
up.
But the real hero worshipping
was reserved for the reception in
the Clipper Room. Thompson
and his entourage climbed ever so
gingerly up the stairs, into the
swarm of fans. Immediately, he
was beseiged with dope-growing
hints, lit hash pipes and the finest
acid this side of Charles St.
Hunter whispered to his aides in
rambling slurred speech, "Hey
get me to the window, too
crowded here, get me some air."
And sure enough, his loyal
keepers took him to the window,
assuring him that he wasn't too
burned out to face the crowd.
But those looking for a crazed
Thompson found exactly that.
Hands trembling as he
chain-smoked Dunhills, his eyes
shifted nervously around the
room as he asked his aides
questions like "Can I turn around
now, nothing behind me, are you
sure it's all right;" and quickly,
his keepers responded "yeah, it's

great, there's no one like him."
Of course, it doesn't really
matter if Thompson's act was
staged or real. People wanted to
see the legendary drug-crazed
writer, someone they understood
and could identify with. They
got what they came for.

College for some a dead-end
(CPS)—There was a time when
going to college was an honor, a
promsiing sign, a good omen for
the future. Jobs were plentiful'
for the upwardly mobile.
College-educated people were
thought to be bound for a better
world, armed with the ability to
think and analyze that they had
acquired in college. If everyone
were college educated, many
people thought, the world would
be a better place to live.
But Caroline Bird, author of
the controversial book The Case
Against College, and a college
graduate herself, argues that
these were just society's myths
during the education boom of
the late fifties and sixties. The
space race with Russia was in
progress and mass higher
education seemed to be the hope
of the future. But statistics in the
early seventies show that many
college graduates are working in
factories, driving cabs or waiting
on tables. It has also become
apparent to some that college
graduates are not the invaluable
commodity they once were
thought to be.
Why then, Bird wonders
rhetorically, are so many young
people still flocking to college,
knowing that four years of
trainign won't insure them a job
in their fields? It is partly the
religion of the liberal arts
education, Bird concludes. A
body of worship has come to
surround the liberally educated
Person. No one dares to propose
that better and more useful
learning can be obtained outside
the university walls. The ideal
Renaissance -style liberal
education is an unquestioned
good.

Ii

But Bird suggests that learning
outside the university would be a
better choice for as many as a
third of the students now in
college who came to get away
from home, to be independent
without really cutting off all ties
or just to pass four years without
having to take an unpromising
job.
Bird's evaluation of the college
experience has been the subject
of heated criticism by college
administrators and students.
Attacks by administrators have
usually centered on her section
concerning college as an
investment. Bird contends that if
a student took the money he
spent on college-related expenses,
added the money he wouldhave
earned working those four years,
and put it all into a bank instead,
by age 60 he would have
accumulated more money than a
college graduate who earned the
average yearly salary for
college-educated workers. In
other words, don't do it for the
money, Bird advises.
Oddly enough, an American
Council of Education survey
showed that more students were
going to college to be "very well
off" in 1974 than in 1966, when
the chances of attaining that goal
soon after college were much
greater.
Attacks by recent graduates
have been harsher and more
angry than those by
administrators and professors,
Bird said in an interview. "I've
received many illiterate attacks
from people who have just
graduated from college, which
proves my point."
"College graduates tend to feel
that by my saying college is not

all that good, I'm taking
something away from them.
They think if I'd only shut up,
things about college would be a
lot better," Bird said.
Bird's critics have also claimed
that college enriches the society
by producing better citizens, but
Bird finds this myth as invalid as
the rest. College doesn't create
bright, ambitious, happy, liberal
people from nothing. The bright,
ambitious, happy, liberal people
are the ones who choose to go to
college. This class selectivity may
become more prevalent as tuition
and expenses rise while loan
money becomes scarcer and more
expensive.
Snobbishness
For now, society uses the
college degree as a kind of
first-round screening in picking
candidates for the future. In
many cases, Bird argues, a college
education is unnecessary since
most jobs require extensive
training that a • person with
common sense could easily pick
up. It is a kind of snobbishness
which is based more on pretense
than reality.
"The bellhop at the hotel
where I stayed last night had a
college degree," Bird said. "If a
hotel can afford to require their
bellhops to have a college degree,
they will. If everybody goes to
college, you can demand a degree
to be a bellhop. It's just like
charging everybody a heavy tax
for getting a job—any job.
. Bird said she hadn't changed
her assessment of college because
of the reactions she has received.
"College is fine if you want it,
but it can't be thrust upon you.
Nobody will stop dead if they
don't go to college."

Unfortunately, Hopkins' possible purchase of the
Baltimorean has aroused the ire of local residents. While we
can understand the community's natural response to having
housing units removed from the market, we feel they have
overreacted to what seems to us to be a reasonable

Of all the buildings in the area the Baltimorean seems to

the residents are on short-term leases.

neighborhood, and consequently make it a safer place for all
residents to live.

the formation of the Student Council's Community Relations
Committee. We never expect area residents to be overjoyed
with a Hopkins purchase of a large bloc of housing, but they
should realize that the University—its students—have certain
needs which must be met in a reasonable manner. While we
realize that the Community may have been abused by
Hopkins in the past, we hope they will act in the spirit of
cooperation and consider the needs of others as we trust the
University will.
